author: Jonathan Lethem
title: “The Starlet Apartments”
description: “The day’s party was under way. Or the previous night’s had never ended.”

author: Leïla Slimani
title: “The Confession”
description: “I cannot say why, but I had the painful impression that I was not the ﬁrst, on that beautiful, sun-drenched day, to press her against the ground and possess her.”

author: T. Coraghessan Boyle
title: “Asleep at the Wheel”
description: “She’s smiling as he comes up to the car, and he’s smiling, too, and now he’s reaching for the door handle . . . but the door seems to be locked, and she’s fumbling for the release.”

author: Emma Cline
title: “What Can You Do with a General”
description: “How had it happened, the eventual neutering of his anger? He was too tired to knock things over.”

author: Haruki Murakami
title: “Cream”
description: “ ‘There’s nothing worth getting in this world that you can get easily,’ the old man had said, with unshakable conviction, like Pythagoras explaining his theorem.”

author: Salvatore Scibona
title: “Do Not Stop”
description: “He heard a whistle and saw his truck blow up and he figured he would be here at Khe Sanh awhile longer.”

author: Amos Oz
title: “All Rivers”
description: “I’m tired of words. You strive to be accurate, and then words come along and falsify everything.”

author: Taymour Soomro
title: “Philosophy of the Foot”
description: “Listen to the foot,” the boy says. “The foot says go forward, go back, stand still. If you listen you’ll know.”

author: Mary Gaitskill
title: “Acceptance Journey”
description: “Somehow, somewhere inside her, love and torture had got squished together. And it wasn’t just in her.”

author: Linn Ullmann
title: “Time for the Eyes to Adjust”
description: “My father has four houses, two cars, five wives, one swimming pool, nine children, and one cinema.”

author: Joy Williams
title: “Chaunt”
description: “When the boys died and after she had buried the one who was hers, she moved to Dove.”

author: Garth Greenwell
title: “The Frog King”
description: “I would get up soon but for now I kept looking at him, his face bearded and dark, smoothed out by sleep.”

author: Sam Lipsyte
title: “Show Recent Some Love”
description: “In the olden days, as I recall, you had your charming pigs and your not so charming pigs. Mike was on the spectrum there.”

author: Scholastique Mukasonga
title: Fiction by Scholastique Mukasonga: “Cattle Praise Song”
description: “Every man had something to say about the cows he’d once owned and those he would perhaps, one day, own again. ”

author: Tony Earley
title: Fiction by Tony Earley: “Backpack”
description: “John began to sense the world unravelling behind him, the tightly braided strands of his life snapping free with sharp cracks.”

author: Bryan Washington
title: Fiction by Bryan Washington: “Waugh”
description: “Rod wasn’t their pimp, but you’d be a fool to tell him that.”

author: Anne Carson
title: “Flaubert Again”
description: “If she were ever really writing, the writing would pull her down into itself and erase everything but her decency. ”

author: Kevin Barry
title: Fiction by Kevin Barry:  “The Coast of Leitrim”
description: “He was tormented now by his own happiness. He could not imagine a future day without Katherine.”

author: John L’Heureux
title: “The Rise and Rise of Annie Clark”
description: “With a prayer of thanks to Jesus, Annie seizes on her power as a modern woman. She will take her life into her own hands and let someone else do all the work for a change.”

author: Yiyun Li
title: “When We Were Happy We Had Other Names”
description: “One morning when Jiayu opened her eyes she said to the ceiling, Grief, I don’t know who you are, so don’t pretend you know who I am.”

author: Ludmilla Petrushevskaya
title: “Poor Girl”
description: “The wretched mother could easily have lost her sanity watching her husband love their daugh­ter.”

author: Tessa Hadley
title: “Cecilia Awakened”
description: “It was as if, on the first morning of that holiday in Florence, Cecilia simply woke up inside the wrong skin.”

author: Saïd Sayrafiezadeh
title: “Audition”
description: “I took my place onstage, apprehensive beneath a single blinding spotlight, and waited for his direction, which was, simply, ‘Show me the color red.’ ”

author: Haruki Murakami
title: “The Wind Cave”
description: “If my little sister really did disappear in the hole, never to return to this world, how would I ever explain that to my parents?”

author: Sana Krasikov
title: “Ways and Means”
description: “Oliver had been placed on indefinite leave. The latest rumor was that another allegation had surfaced.”

author: Richard Ford
title: “Displaced”
description: “He was the only friend I had. If I lost him, I might as well give up on life.”

author: T. Coraghessan Boyle
title: Fiction by T. Coraghessan Boyle: “I Walk Between the Raindrops”
description: “While it’s harsh to say it, this is what I’m getting at here: some people are doomed from the start.”

author: Zadie Smith
title: Fiction by Zadie Smith: “Now More Than Ever”
description: “I instinctively sympathize with the guilty. That’s my guilty secret.”

author: Lauren Groff
title: “Under the Wave”
description: “Out of the wildness, the branch of an oak plucked her from the water and she clung there, animal, as orange dawned over the marsh made alien with mud.”

author: Joseph O’Neill
title: “The First World”
description: “My marriage came to an end, with consequences that were almost all beyond my powers of anticipation.”

author: Gary Shteyngart
title: “The Luck of Kokura”
description: “You execute one good trade, and people will listen to everything you say for the next five years.”

author: Weike Wang
title: “Omakase”
description: “She didn’t want to sound insane, yet she also didn’t want to be a quiet little flower. So there she was, saying nothing but oscillating between these two extremes.”

author: David Gilbert
title: “Fungus”
description: “How often does a person let his six-year-old decide all on her own?”

author: Karen Russell
title: “Orange World”
description: “Orange World is a nest of tangled electrical cords and open drawers ﬁlled with steak knives. It’s a baby’s fat hand hovering over the blushing coils of a toaster oven.”

author: Lu Yang
title: “Silver Tiger”
description: “I fought the silver tiger for three days and three nights. During those three days and nights I lost all awareness of anything else in the hospital.”

author: Ben Marcus
title: “Stay Down and Take It”
description: “There is only one road out of here, and everyone we know is on it, moaning silently, I imagine, gently rending their summer linens at this unwelcome disruption.”

author: John L’Heureux
title: “The Long Black Line”
description: “The best thing he could do with his life was sacrifice it, and what better way to sacrifice it than as a Jesuit.”

author: Edwidge Danticat
title: “Without Inspection”
description: “He’d learned, while at sea, that time can stretch endlessly and that wind and air can suck you dry, forcing you to see what is not there.”

author: Isaac Bashevis Singer
title: “The Boarder”
description: A previously unpublished story by the Nobel laureate and National Book Award winner, who likely translated it himself.

author: Robert Coover
title: “Treatments”
description: “Life, he has always believed, is a comedy, but this isn’t very funny.”

author: Yiyun Li
title: “A Flawless Silence”
description: “Could love find a place in a marriage if it had not started with some degree of fantasy?”

author: Keith Gessen
title: “How Did We Come to Know You?”
description: “I thought maybe I was getting the hang of this country, this life. And then my grandmother fell down the stairs.”

author: Camille Bordas
title: “The State of Nature”
description: “My mother was glad about the burglary, in a way. She got to use all the knowledge that she’d gleaned from reading crime novels.”

author: Sam Allingham
title: “The Intermediate Class”
description: “When I ring this bell, we will no longer speak English. If anyone speaks English, I will act as if I don’t understand.”

author: Tommy Orange
title: “The State”
description: “You’re from a people who took and took and took and took. And from a people taken. You’re both and neither.”

author: Gish Jen
title: “No More Maybe”
description: “We carry our visas everywhere, and keep a list of places we should not go. Texas. New Hampshire. Alabama.”

author: Joseph O’Neill
title: “The Poltroon Husband”
description: “I didn’t press Jayne further. If there’s one thing I’m not, it’s an interrogator. I decided to bide my time.”

author: Nicole Krauss
title: “Seeing Ershadi”
description: “His face did something to me. Or, rather, the film, with its compassion and its utterly jarring ending, did something to me.”

author: William Trevor
title: “Mrs. Crasthorpe”
description: “She’d been impulsive once upon a time, hasty and not caring that she was. Tups had called her a spur-of-the-moment girl.”

author: Rachel Kushner
title: “Stanville”
description: “Gordon had dreaded death row but found that it didn’t quite conform to his nightmares.”

author: Jeffrey Eugenides
title: “Bronze”
description: “Eugene’s little secret? He wanted to be beautiful. If that didn’t work, noticeable would do.”

author: Jhumpa Lahiri
title: “The Boundary”
description: “After just a few hours, it’s as if they’d always lived here. The things they’ve brought for a week in the country are scattered all over the place.”

author: John Edgar Wideman
title: “Writing Teacher”
description: “Show not tell. Don’t bother telling me or telling a young woman you are on her side and wish to help. She doesn’t need that kind of help.”

author: David Gates
title: “Texas”
description: “What was he doing in this room with these young people? His wife used to sit in that chair. He used to sit where this young man was.”

author: Sadia Shepard
title: “Foreign-Returned”
description: “He had spent his entire life in Pakistan as part of the majority. What would it feel like, he wondered, to consider America home?”

author: Colin Barrett
title: “Whoever Is There, Come on Through”
description: “Being depressed is like being in a dream. The suspicion is that everyone you meet is actually depressed, too, only they don’t know it.”

author: Zadie Smith
title: “The Lazy River”
description: “We are on vacation, from life and from struggle both. We are ‘going with the ﬂow.’”

author: Kristen Roupenian
title: “Cat Person”
description: “It was a terrible kiss, shockingly bad; Margot had trouble believing that a grown man could possibly be so bad at kissing.”

author: J. M. Coetzee
title: “The Dog”
description: “It sends him into ecstasies of rage, this whiff of fear coming off the being on the other side of the gate.”

author: Will Mackin
title: “The Lost Troop”
description: “We could have left it all behind, walked off the outpost into the desert, never to be seen again.”

author: David Gilbert
title: “The Sightseers”
description: Fiction: “For the most part the biggest sin was the old sin of being ugly Americans.”

author: Thomas McGuane
title: “Riddle”
description: “We don’t remember everything, but I’d love to know who’s in charge of what we forget. If there’s a system, it escapes me.”

author: Anne Enright
title: “The Hotel”
description: “There was no one to ask which way to go. No cleaners, no security, no passengers pulling luggage or pushing trolleys in hijabs or shorts or travelling shawls.”

author: Joseph O’Neill
title: “The Sinking of the Houston”
description: “When I became a parent of young children I also became a purposeful and relentless opportunist of sleep.”

author: Denis Johnson
title: “Strangler Bob”
description: “Most of us would have ﬁt in perfectly in a psych ward. Many of us had already been there.”

author: Tessa Hadley
title: “Funny Little Snake”
description: “Valerie wouldn’t have guessed that the child had it in her, to enter so completely into a life other than her own.”

author: Sarah Shun-lien Bynum
title: “Likes”
description: “The dad scrolled through his daughter’s Instagram account, looking for clues.”

author: Ben Marcus
title: “Blueprints for St. Louis”
description: “They’d been friends once, before they’d got into designing memorials for unspeakable catastrophes.”

author: Jonas Hassen Khemiri
title: “As You Would Have Told It to Me (Sort Of) If We Had Known Each Other Before You Died”
description: “Eight months later I died in a moped accident in Portugal. One week later I was resurrected in Stockholm.”

author: Edwidge Danticat
title: “Sunrise, Sunset”
description: “What if this is the last day that she recalls anything? What if she never recognizes anyone again?”

author: Allegra Goodman
title: “F.A.Q.s”
description: “It couldn’t last, this secret life, this music in plain sight.”

author: Miranda July
title: “The Metal Bowl”
description: “It happened in an apartment, on an old couch. I wasn’t directed so much as given a series of props to make my way through, like an obstacle course.”

author: Lauren Groff
title: “Dogs Go Wolf”
description: “They’d been left alone on the island, the two little girls. Four and seven.”

author: Garth Greenwell
title: “An Evening Out”
description: “I knew I was acting badly, that I was looking too brazenly and too long, that I shouldn’t have looked at all.”

author: Don DeLillo
title: “The Itch”
description: “Certain days it’s the left wrist. Upper arms at home in the evening. Thighs and shins most likely at night. ”

author: Kirstin Valdez Quade
title: “Christina the Astonishing (1150-1224)”
description: “On the day of Christina’s exorcism, the Saracens stormed the Holy Land.”

author: Cristina Henríquez
title: “Everything Is Far from Here”
description: “ ‘Did you see a little boy?’ she asks every new arrival. ‘A boy who looks like me?’ ”

author: Hye-young Pyun
title: “Caring for Plants”
description: “Oghi knew that his mother-in-law was worried about him. He also knew that she blamed him. He was the reason that her one and only child was gone.”

author: Italo Calvino
title: “The Adventure of a Skier”
description: “One by one they fell, backward or forward, and he alone was cutting through the air, bent double over his skis, until he saw her.”

author: William Trevor
title: “The Piano Teacher’s Pupil”
description: Fiction: “Within this small boy, so modest in his manner, there were symphonies unwritten, suites and concertos and oratorios.”

author: Andrew Sean Greer
title: “It’s a Summer Day”
description: Fiction: “He is nominated for a prize no one believes he will win. Not his agent, who urged him to stay home and start a new book.”

author: Will Mackin
title: “Crossing the River No Name”
description: Fiction: “One rainy night, in March, 2009, we crossed a muddy ﬁeld to intercept a group of Taliban who’d come out of the mountains of Pakistan.”

author: Sherman Alexie
title: “Clean, Cleaner, Cleanest”
description: Fiction: “She was a motel maid, but it helped to think like a doctor or a nurse. It helped to think that she was helping other people.”

author: Curtis Sittenfeld
title: “Show Don’t Tell”
description: Fiction: “The difference between who I was then and who I am now is that now I never assume that anyone I encounter shares my opinion about anything.”

author: Samanta Schweblin
title: “The Size of Things”
description: Fiction: “Only once I was inside did I realize that leaving Duvel there alone had been a tremendous mistake.”

author: Samantha Hunt
title: “A Love Story”
description: Fiction: “The list of potential reasons that my husband and I no longer have sex wakes me up at night. If I’m not already awake thinking about the coyotes.”

author: Etgar Keret
title: “Fly Already”
description: Fiction: “Maybe he changed his mind and went back inside, I try to tell myself. But I don’t believe it.”

author: Yiyun Li
title: “A Small Flame”
description: Fiction: “Those who allow themselves to be hurt in the name of love must understand better than anyone the desire to hurt.”

author: David Means
title: “Two Ruminations on a Homeless Brother”
description: Fiction: “Those who were once known as mad, Skid Row bums, stumblebums and drunkards and junkies were now seen as diseased victims who might be treated.”

author: Lara Vapnyar
title: “Deaf and Blind”
description: Fiction: “Although I didn’t know anything about sex, I understood what there was to understand about lovers.”

author: Akhil Sharma
title: “You Are Happy?”
description: Fiction: “Lakshman, watching his mother, felt that what she was planning was so bizarre that it could not possibly happen.”

author: Emma Cline
title: “Northeast Regional”
description: Fiction: “They were the type of women whose own sorrow moved them immeasurably. Who wanted to recount the details of their worst tragedies in the lull after sex.”

author: John Lanchester
title: “Signal”
description: Fiction: “You aren’t allowed to ask for the Wi-Fi password before you say hello.”

author: Victor Lodato
title: “Herman Melville, Volume I”
description: Fiction: “Good teeth, she’s learned, are like a passport: they helped you cross borders.”

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
title: “I.O.U.”
description: A previously unpublished short story from 1920.

author: Anne Enright
title: “Solstice”
description: Fiction: “It felt like the end of things. Made you want your religion back.”

author: Zadie Smith
title: “Crazy They Call Me”
description: Fiction: “Not only is there no more Eleanora, there isn’t any Billie, either. There is only Lady Day.”

author: Lore Segal
title: “Ladies’ Lunch”
description: Fiction: “The five women have grown old coming together, every other month or so for the last thirty or more years, around one another’s table.”

author: Curtis Sittenfeld
title: “The Prairie Wife”
description: Fiction: “Kirsten’s commute is when she really focusses on whether she has the power to destroy Lucy Headrick’s life.”

author: David Gilbert
title: “Underground”
description: Fiction: “Love, in all forms, had turned into a kind of regret.”

author: Alix Ohlin
title: “Quarantine”
description: Fiction: “She found it hurtful to see other people’s smiling, healthy families or, even worse, to hear about lives that seemed as fragile as her own.”

author: Elif Batuman
title: “Constructed Worlds”
description: Fiction: “Every time I looked up, Einstein seemed to be looking back at me in an expectant way, as if to say, Now what?”

author: Thomas Pierce
title: “Chairman Spaceman”
description: Fiction: “Jerome, with a very serious expression, asked what Dom would do if an alien wanted to have sex with him.”

author: Yiyun Li
title: “On the Street Where You Live”
description: Fiction: “You can’t share with others who your child truly is.”

author: Camille Bordas
title: “Most Die Young”
description: Fiction: “Shyness, fear, and timidity are highly valued among the Pawong.”

author: Mariana Enriquez
title: “Spiderweb”
description: Fiction: “I fell in love too quickly, I got married impetuously, and now I was living with Juan Martín, who irritated and bored me.”

author: Joseph O’Neill
title: “Pardon Edward Snowden”
description: Fiction: “The poet Mark McCain received an e-mail inviting him to sign a ‘poetition’ requesting that President Obama pardon Edward Snowden.”

author: Sam Shepard
title: “Tiny Man”
description: Fiction: “Early morning: They deliver my father’s corpse in the trunk of a ’49 Mercury coupe, dew still heavy on the taillights.”

author: Robert Coover
title: “The Hanging of the Schoolmarm”
description: Fiction: “The schoolmarm’s just showing off again, making their brains ache, unrepentant criminal that she is.”

author: Lauren Groff
title: “Flower Hunters”
description: Fiction: “What is it about me that people need breaks from? she asks the dog.”

author: Mohsin Hamid
title: “Of Windows and Doors”
description: Fiction: “Rumors had begun to circulate of doors that could take you elsewhere, often to places far away, well removed from this death trap of a country.”

author: T. Coraghessan Boyle
title: “Are We Not Men?”
description: Fiction: "In a room at GenLab, Connie and I were presented with an exhaustive menu of just how our chromosomes could be made to match up.”

author: Anne Carson
title: Back the Way You Went
description: Fiction: “What would they have seen if they’d gazed into each other’s depths? But they didn’t.”

author: Ottessa Moshfegh
title: “An Honest Woman”
description: Fiction: “Jeb could hear almost everything that went on in her house, he’d ﬁgured out, if he listened carefully from his basement window.”

author: Cynan Jones
title: “The Edge of the Shoal”
description: Fiction: “It is cold and it is pitch-black. Blacker when he opens his eyes, blacker than it was when they were closed—a stunning nothingness.”

author: Kevin Barry
title: “Deer Season”
description: Fiction: “It’s the sort of thing that could get me in a lot of trouble around here,” he said. “Who’ll know?” she said.

author: Etgar Keret
title: “To the Moon and Back”
description: Fiction: “Lidor looks at me like I’m some kind of a superhero. There’s nothing greater than to have your kid look at you that way.”

author: Petina Gappah
title: “A Short History of Zaka the Zulu”
description: Fiction: “How could any of us have imagined, in the innocence of those days, that there had been this darkness at the school?”

author: Rivka Galchen
title: “How Can I Help?”
description: Fiction: “I like and admire Hayley; she is a team player. I don’t judge. But I have of late been tempted to judge.”

author: Robert Coover
title: “Invasion of the Martians”
description: “He explained to them, politely, that there were certain obligatory regulations, and they shot him.”

author: Jonathan Lethem
title: “A Gentleman’s Game”
description: Fiction: “Bruno had for his entire life associated backgammon with candor, the dice not determining fate so much as revealing character.”

author: Curtis Sittenfeld
title: “Gender Studies”
description: Fiction: “Having a drink in the hotel bar with Luke the Shuttle Driver is almost enjoyable, because it’s like an anthropological experience.”

author: Thomas McGuane
title: “Papaya”
description: Fiction: “She helped him to understand that he had been robbed of everything, his boat stolen.”

author: Tessa Hadley
title: “Dido’s Lament”
description: Fiction: “How worldly was he, coolly inviting her to trespass on the grounds of his second marriage?”

author: Joshua Ferris
title: “The Abandonment”
description: Fiction: “The poor girl. She’s about to burn her life to the ground and she doesn’t even know it.”

author: Joy Williams
title: “Stuff”
description: Fiction: “He felt blue. He was dying, and the doctor, or whoever that had been, hadn’t even given him a prescription to ﬁll.”

author: Michael Andreasen
title: “The King’s Teacup at Rest”
description: Fiction: “The royal steward returns the amusement park’s deed to his crocodile-leather attaché case and addresses the king.”

author: T. Coraghessan Boyle
title: “The Fugitive”
description: Fiction: “What he was about to do was wrong, he knew that, and he regretted it the instant he saw it before him, but he wasn’t going to any prison, no way.”

author: Paul Theroux
title: “Upside-Down Cake”
description: Fiction: “We had betrayed one another too many times to be able to sit comfortably around the same table together.”

author: Karen Russell
title: “Bog Girl”
description: Fiction: “She had been killed, and now her smile seemed even more impressive to him, and he wanted only to protect her from future harm.”

author: Zadie Smith
title: “Two Men Arrive in a Village”
description: Fiction: “A kind of wildness descends, a bloody chaos, into which all the formal gestures of welcome and food and threat seem instantly to dissolve.”

author: Jonathan Safran Foer
title: “Maybe It Was the Distance”
description: Fiction: “All that should have led Jacob to dislike Tamir brought him closer—not with envy but with love.”

author: Ben Lerner
title: “The Polish Rider”
description: Fiction: “She ran after the Uber, screaming for it to stop, until it had turned off her street toward Delancey.”

author: Langston Hughes
title: “Seven People Dancing”
description: A previously unpublished story, written circa 1961.

author: Charles Yu
title: “Fable”
description: Fiction: “Once upon a time, there was an angry guy, who hated the story he was in. All right?”

author: Lauren Groff
title: “The Midnight Zone”
description: Fiction: “If anyone was going to die it was going to be us, our skulls popping in the jaws of an endangered cat.”

author: Akhil Sharma
title: “A Life of Adventure and Delight”
description: Fiction: “Gautama’s favorite thing about hiring prostitutes was negotiating the price.”

author: John L’Heureux
title: “Three Short Moments in a Long Life”
description: Fiction: “I tripped on the new carpet and heard myself saying, ‘Jesus Christ!’ I opened the door and it was him.”

author: Alexandra Kleeman
title: “Choking Victim”
description: Fiction: “She looked down at the small ears of her daughter, unavoidably open to the world, eagerly capturing the sounds of the choking man.”

author: Lara Vapnyar
title: “Waiting for the Miracle”
description: Fiction: “Vadik said in Russian that he was spending the night in the city. With a girl. An American girl.”

author: Colin Barrett
title: “Anhedonia, Here I Come”
description: Fiction:“Bobby had been writing and rewriting and refining and re-refining the manuscript of his début collection for more than eight years now.”

author: Sarah Shun-lien Bynum
title: “The Burglar”
description: Fiction: “What sorts of crimes are committed by an unjustly incarcerated man who’s travelled through a rift in the space-time continuum?”

author: Kevin Canty
title: “God’s Work”
description: Fiction: “Where is the holy part of him? He can’t find it, only sin.”

author: Ian McEwan
title: “My Purple Scented Novel”
description: Fiction: “I don’t deny there was wrongdoing. I stole a life, and I don’t intend to give it back.”

author: Annie Proulx
title: “A Resolute Man”
description: Fiction: “Was it not his responsibility to save the woman who had saved him?”

author: Ann Beattie
title: “For the Best”
description: Fiction: “Where had she come from tonight, and where was she returning to? He had no idea.”

author: Fiona McFarlane
title: “Buttony”
description: Fiction: “The children stood motionless in the circle, and now their hands were closed.”

author: Luke Mogelson
title: “Total Solar”
description: Fiction: “She was new to Kabul and, I sensed, typically stimulated by the proximity of violence and privation.”

author: Don DeLillo
title: “Sine Cosine Tangent”
description: New fiction: “I liked reading books that nearly killed me, books that helped tell me who I was, the son who spites his father by reading such books.”

author: George Saunders
title: “Mother’s Day”
description: Fiction: “Well, if he wanted a fight, she knew how to fight. She liked it. She was good at it. She’d make him pay. The way she always had.”

author: Adam Ehrlich Sachs
title: “The Philosophers”
description: Fiction: “Until recently, he told the psychiatrist, he had been the most intelligent person in history.”

author: Tatyana Tolstaya
title: Aspic
description: “It’s a special kind of religion, making the aspic. It’s a yearly sacrifice, though we don’t know to whom or for what.”

author: Ludmilla Petrushevskaya
title: “The Story of a Painter”
description: Fiction: “He could no longer pretend that his life wasn’t a total failure and that nothing except art concerned him.”

author: Anne Carson
description: Fiction: “What is the price of desolation, and who pays.”

author: Ottessa Moshfegh
title: “The Beach Boy”
description: “He’d lived his entire life on his best behavior, a slave to decorum. For what?”

author: Tim Parks
title: “Bedtimes”
description: Fiction: “He wonders, Should he wait up for his wife and confront her?”

author: Dana Spiotta
title: “Jelly and Jack”
description: Fiction: “All his circling around eventually came to the point. ‘What do you look like?’ ”

author: Martin Amis
title: “Oktober”
description: Fiction: “The crowd was diversified by thin streams of dark-skinned and dark-clothed refugees, their eyes haunted and determined, their tread leaden but firm.”

author: Rachel Kushner
title: “Fifty-Seven”
description: Fiction: “He didn’t intend to hurt her. As soon as he could get something oﬀ her, he’d leave her alone, let her go.”

author: Ann Beattie
title: Save a Horse Ride a Cowgirl
description: Fiction: “You couldn’t just stare into the darkness with binoculars, looking at your old life.”

author: Mark Haddon
title: “The Weir”
description: Fiction: “He realizes how big the river is, now that he is inside it, how strong, how lost the woman must be, and how slim his chances are of ﬁnding her.”

author: Julianne Pachico
title: “Honey Bunny”
description: Fiction: A wealthy young Colombian woman in New York takes refuge in cocaine and recalls the country she had to leave behind.

author: Ariel Dorfman
title: “The Gospel According to García”
description: Fiction: “García was not able to teach that day, because of circumstances that were best left unspoken.”

author: Lesley Nneka Arimah
title: “Who Will Greet You at Home”
description: Fiction: “Ogechi tried to think of it as a fair trade, a little bit of her life for her child’s life.”

author: Ben Marcus
title: “Cold Little Bird”
description: Fiction: “Of course a child could do it. Who else but children to lead the fucking species into darkness?”

author: Rivka Galchen
title: “Usl at the Stadium”
description: Fiction: For a few minutes, his sleeping form was on the Jumbotron. The next day, he was all over the Internet.

author: Tim Parks
title: “Vespa”
description: Fiction: “Riding always induced a happy mood of freedom and competence, which vanished the moment he took the helmet oﬀ.”

author: Thomas McGuane
title: “The Driver”
description: Fiction: “As the car pulled forward, Spencer looked longingly into the dark. He thought of his mother and wondered if she would remember to feed the ﬁsh.”

author: Amos Oz
title: “My Curls Have Blown All the Way to China”
description: Fiction: “What foolishness, to go and get my hair cut. . . . And on that very same morning.”

author: Joy Williams
title: “Chicken Hill”
description: Fiction: “Imagination only fails us in the end, when the stories we tell ourselves have to stop.”

author: Danielle McLaughlin
title: “In the Act of Falling”
description: New fiction: Life is transformed for a family in the wake of Ireland’s financial crisis.

author: Jensen Beach
title: “The Apartment”
description: Fiction: A new neighbor prompts memories of a long-lost lover for a woman caught in an unhappy marriage.

author: Alice McDermott
title: “These Short, Dark Days”
description: In a new story, a nun copes with a death in turn-of-the-century Brooklyn.

author: Michael Cunningham
title: “Little Man”
description: Fiction: “Rumpelstiltskin,” reinvented.

author: Heinz Insu Fenkl
title: “Five Arrows”
description: New fiction: A boy visits his uncle in the Korean countryside, and hears the tale of the night he was seduced by a ghost in the woods.

author: Tessa Hadley
title: “Silk Brocade”
description: New fiction: “It was about a wedding dress, of course. The wedding would be in June, Nola said.”

author: Lauren Groff
title: “Ghosts and Empties”
description: In a new story, a young mother walks the streets of her neighborhood at night, watching the lives of her neighbors as she escapes her own.

author: Alejandro Zambra
title: Reading Comprehension: Text No. 1
description: Fiction by Alejandro Zambra: “ ‘The National Institute is rotten, but the world is rotten,’ he said. ‘They prepared you for this.’ ”

author: Louise Erdrich
title: “The Flower”
description: A new story: An Ojibwe girl and a white clerk make a daring escape through the frozen north.

author: Ben Marcus
title: “The Grow-Light Blues”
description: A new story: When a tech company develops a radical nutrition system, an employee becomes a guinea pig and a martyr.

author: Zadie Smith
title: “Escape from New York”
description: “He could not get over how well he was handling the apocalypse so far.”

author: Primo Levi
title: Quaestio de Centauris
description: “Despite his two hundred and sixty years, his appearance was youthful, in both his human and his equine aspects.”

author: Jonathan Franzen
title: “The Republic of Bad Taste”
description: “He didn’t want this to be just another seduction. He wanted her to be the way out of the wasteland of seduction he’d been living in.”

author: Karen Russell
title: “The Prospectors”
description: A new story: “Perhaps the knowledge of one’s death, ceaselessly swallowed, is the very food you need to become a ghost.”

author: Jonathan Safran Foer
title: “Love Is Blind and Deaf”
description: “They ate apples when they ate and, after a while, they knew it all.”

author: Salman Rushdie
title: “The Duniazát”
description: New fiction: “Being a man of reason, Ibn Rushd did not guess that the girl was a supernatural creature, a jinnia.”

author: Dorthe Nors
title: “The Freezer Chest”
description: New fiction: “That’s how I recall it, a great lid, and beneath it a frozen darkness that was all my own.”

author: Justin Taylor
title: “So You’re Just What, Gone?”
description: New fiction: “There are literally dozens of texts from Mark Perv waiting for her, which is both surprising and not.”

author: Sheila Heti
title: “My Life Is a Joke”
description: New fiction: “That is how I died—as a chicken crossing the road to get to the other side.”

author: Milan Kundera
title: “The Apologizer”
description: New fiction: “He was gentle and intelligent like his father; and he would always be an intruder, as his mother had viewed him.”

author: Luke Mogelson
title: Peacetime
description: Fiction by Luke Mogelson: “I was living in the armory on Lexington Avenue. First Sergeant Diaz had given me the keys.”

author: Ann Beattie
title: Major Maybe
description: Fiction: “We were so simpatico we morphed into an old married couple, in speeded-up time.”

author: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
title: “Apollo”
description: New fiction: “Nothing changed when Raphael came to live with us, not at first.”

author: Kamel Daoud
title: “Musa”
description: The brother of the Arab murdered in Albert Camus’s “The Stranger” tells his story.

author: Thomas Pierce
title: This Is an Alert
description: New fiction: “Somewhere up there, above the clouds, in the high hazy blue-black atmosphere, the war is being fought.”

author: Colm Tóibín
title: “Sleep”
description: New fiction: “He is, he says, going to use hypnosis. We will both need to be quiet.”

author: Sarah Braunstein
title: “All You Have to Do”
description: New fiction: “This was at a point in Sid’s life when he was still ﬂattered when an older man shook his hand.”

author: Stephen King
title: “A Death”
description: New fiction: “At noon on the day of Rebecca Cline’s murder, there had been a birthday party, with cake and ice cream.”

author: Haruki Murakami
title: Kino
description: New fiction: “There was something about him that stirred up the dark side in other people.”

author: Amelia Gray
title: Labyrinth
description: New fiction by Amelia Gray: “‘He’s got balls,’ said Dale, a true friend.”

author: Robert Stone
title: Helping
description: Fiction by Robert Stone: “Day in, day out, he was sober. At times, it was almost stimulating.”

author: Toni Morrison
title: Sweetness
description: New fiction by Toni Morrison: “With that skin, there was no point in being tough or sassy, even when you were right.”

author: Elizabeth Harrower
title: Alice
description: Fiction by Elizabeth Harrower: “The question was: Could one terribly good girl ever, in her mother’s eyes, equal one boy? And the answer was no.”

author: Isaac Bashevis Singer
title: Inventions
description: Fiction by Isaac Bashevis Singer: “There are facts that a man must disown, even to himself. There are secrets one must take to the grave.”

author: J. Robert Lennon
title: Breadman
description: New fiction by J. Robert Lennon: “The flour seemed a bit theatrical to me—yes, he was a baker, but were these the clothes he baked in?”

author: Robert Coover
title: The Crabapple Tree
description: New fiction by Robert Coover: “Over the years, we got used to thinking of Marleen as something eerie but mostly harmless at the edge of our lives.”

author: Colin Barrett
title: The Ways
description: New fiction by Colin Barrett: “Off school, and drinking when she liked: Pell had Nick under her thumb.”

author: Nuruddin Farah
title: The Start of the Affair
description: New fiction by Nuruddin Farah: “He wishes he were an artist and Ahmed a nude subject, posing to be drawn.”

author: Elizabeth McKenzie
title: Savage Breast
description: New fiction by Elizabeth McKenzie. “Mama?” I called, even though of course she was no longer living. Instead, a large beast swept in.

author: Tim Parks
title: Reverend
description: New fiction by Tim Parks: “He was always ready to be meeting people. To be saving their souls.”

author: Etgar Keret
title: One Gram Short
description: New fiction by Etgar Keret: “All I want is a single bud, even a joint, to smoke with a pretty girl who laughs at my jokes.“

author: Brad Watson
title: Eykelboom
description: New fiction by Brad Watson: “What he had done to bring down his father’s wrath no one knew.”

author: Dave Eggers
title: “The Alaska of Giants and Gods”
description: “The Lower Forty-eight was full of cowards and thieves and it was time for mountains and people of truth and courage.”

author: Antonya Nelson
title: Primum Non Nocere
description: New fiction by Antonya Nelson: “Maybe all mothers existed in order to torment their daughters with news of the future.”

author: Jess Row
title: The Empties
description: New fiction by Jess Row. “Some people, you get a little liquor in them and it’s all about the old times. They want to huddle up and sing Lady Gaga.”

author: Tom Hanks
title: Alan Bean Plus Four
description: Fiction by Tom Hanks: “We took hundreds of selﬁes with the Earth in the window.”

author: Kirstin Valdez Quade
title: Ordinary Sins
description: Fiction by Kirstin Valdez Quade: Last night, Crystal dreamed she was sitting naked on the church’s rectory couch.

author: Haruki Murakami
title: Scheherazade
description: Fiction by Haruki Murakami: “Each time they had sex, she told Habara a strange and gripping story afterward.”

author: Kevin Canty
title: Story, With Bird
description: Fiction by Kevin Canty: “The world divided itself into the drinking and the hangover, day and night, and we lived for the nights.”

author: Paul La Farge
title: Rosendale
description: “One night they had a contest to see who could write the most frightening story. . . .” Fiction by Paul La Farge.

author: Victor Lodato
title: Jack, July
description: Fiction by Victor Lodato: “Soon, he knew, the freak would come, the soul-suck, if he didn’t get one of two things: more crystal or a sound sleep.”

author: Danielle McLaughlin
title: The Dinosaurs on Other Planets
description: Fiction by Danielle McLaughlin: “It was dizzying: the unimaginable expanses of space and time, the vast, spinning universe.”

author: Thomas McGuane
title: Motherlode
description: Fiction by Thomas McGuane: “He should have spent the day at Jorgensen’s with his arm up a cow’s ass.... But the roll of money in Ray’s pack made him wonder how anxious he was to get back to work.”

author: Joseph O’Neill
title: The Referees
description: Fiction by Joseph O’Neill. “There are a lot of ethical, pleasant, and dependable people notionally out there. It’s intimidating, frankly.”

author: Tessa Hadley
title: One Saturday Morning
description: Fiction by Tessa Hadley. “She couldn’t get rid of the terrible knowledge that Dom had brought; it seemed to be stuck inside her, in her stomach or her throat.”

author: César Aira
title: Picasso
description: Would you rather have a Picasso or be Picasso? Fiction by César Aira.

author: Paul Theroux
title: Action
description: Fiction by Paul Theroux: “It all stank pleasantly of wickedness, and if I’d known anything I would have recognized it as sensual. But I was ﬁfteen, small for my age, soon to enter my sophomore year of high school. Away from my house I wasn’t sure who I was; I had no self, nothing to put forward, no idea that I dared express, no voice, nothing but the bravado I’d learned from Eddie.”

author: Roberto Bolaño
title: Clara
description: Fiction by Roberto Bolaño: “Clara” At the start, it all went fine; then Clara returned to the city where she lived, in the south of Spain (she’d been on vacation in Barcelona), and everything began to fall apart.

author: Justin Torres
title: Reverting to a Wild State
description: A breakup, in reverse.

author: Saïd Sayrafiezadeh

description: What should you do when you learn your mother has only a few months to live? A son grapples with his mother’s impending death in Saïd Sayrafiezadeh’s story.

author: David Gilbert
title: Here’s the Story
description: “It ends with his right hand gripping her left, the curve of her knuckles the pulling yoke. The plane is on its final approach.”

author: Shirley Jackson
title: Fiction by Shirley Jackson: The Man in the Woods
description: A short story by Jackson, from 2014.

author: Jonathan Lethem
title: “Pending Vegan”
description: Fiction: No one knew that Paul Espeseth had renamed himself Pending Vegan. His new name was a mortification, yes, but he clung to it, for it also held some promise of an exalted life, one just beyond reach.

author: Tessa Hadley
title: Under the Sign of the Moon

author: Denis Johnson
title: The Largesse of the Sea Maiden

author: Donald Antrim
title: The Emerald Light in the Air

author: Akhil Sharma
title: A Mistake
description: Fiction by Akhil Sharma: “As far back as I can remember, my parents have bothered each other.”

author: Dinaw Mengestu
title: “The Paper Revolution”
description: Fiction: “For weeks we were like visitors in our real lives.”

author: Rebecca Curtis
title: The Christmas Miracle
description: “When I arrived in Revelstoke for the holiday, everyone was still shell-shocked about the cat deaths.”

author: James Thurber
title: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty
description: Fiction: “ ‘I’m not asking you, Lieutenant Berg,’ said the Commander. ‘Throw on the power lights!’ ”

author: Rivka Galchen
title: The Late Novels of Gene Hackman

author: Alice Munro
title: The Bear Came Over the Mountain
description: A man loses his wife to Alzheimer’s disease. Does he also have to lose her to another man?

author: Joshua Ferris
title: The Breeze
description: Fiction by Joshua Ferris: “The Breeze” The breeze, God, the breeze! she thought. You get how many like it? Maybe a dozen in a lifetime . . . and already gone, down the block and picking up speed, or dying out. What if she failed to make the most of what remained of this perfect spring day?

author: Paul Theroux
title: I’M the Meat, You’Re the Knife

author: Shirley Jackson
title: Fiction by Shirley Jackson: Paranoia
description: A short story by Jackson, from 2013.

author: Dashiell Hammett
title: An Inch And a Half of Glory

author: Colm Tóibín
title: Summer of ’38
description: Fiction by Colm Tóibín: “Summer of ’38” Rudolfo would be over eighty now, she calculated. Maybe he would still have something of the effortless charm that had come to him that summer as naturally as light did to the morning.

author: Will Mackin
title: Will Mackin: "Kattekoppen"
description: “Before a mission, I’d study the contour lines within the map circles in order to understand how to navigate the rise and fall of the terrain.”

author: Zadie Smith
title: “The Embassy of Cambodia”
description: “Who would expect the Embassy of Cambodia? Nobody. Nobody could have expected it, or be expecting it. It’s a surprise, to us all.”

author: Marisa Silver
title: Creatures
description: Fiction by Marisa Silver: “All boys play with guns, James thought suddenly, the defensive rage he’d felt that morning at the preschool resurging.”

author: David Gilbert
title: Member / Guest
description: “Sometimes I feel like a spy, like a double agent, and one day I’m going to give up the goods on all these people here.”

author: Alice Munro
title: “Amundsen”
description: Fiction: “On the bench outside the station, I sat and waited.”

author: Zadie Smith
title: “Permission to Enter”
description: Fiction: “In the child’s mind, a breach now appeared: between what she believed she knew of herself, essentially, and her essence as others seemed to understand it.”

author: Junot Díaz
title: The Cheater’s Guide to Love
description: Confessions of a self-professed Casanova.

author: Tessa Hadley
title: An Abduction
description: “Jane Allsop was abducted when she was fifteen, and nobody noticed.”

author: Shani Boianjiu
title: Shani Boianjiu: “Means of Suppressing Demonstrations’”
description: “She knew that her military service was approaching its end, but could not feel it.”

author: Jennifer Egan
title: Black Box
description: “Knowing your latitude and longitude is not the same as knowing where you are.”

author: Maile Meloy
title: The Proxy Marriage
description: Fiction by Maile Meloy: “The Proxy Marriage” Bridey’s father came to her and William with a request. He’d been asked to arrange a proxy wedding for a Marine corporal in Kandahar and his fiancée, who was in North Carolina and pregnant. Would they be the proxies?

author: Michael Chabon
title: Citizen Conn
description: What was it that drove two best friends and collaborators—creators of cult comic books—apart?

author: Alice McDermott
title: “Someone”
description: “It must have been second nature to him, this veering attention. But for her it was both devastating and thrilling.”

author: Saïd Sayrafiezadeh
title: A Brief Encounter with the Enemy

author: Nathan Englander
title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Anne Frank

author: George Saunders
title: “Tenth of December”
description: “Wasn’t overcoming this feeling of fear what truly distinguished the brave?”

author: Ann Beattie
title: “Starlight”
description: Fiction: “If it has to be done, it has to be done. Ollie’s been here for all of it, so of course he’s here for the final photograph of the Nixons in the White House.”

author: Robert Coover
title: “Matinée”
description: “She takes her favorite seat in the middle of the seventh row, hoping to experience once again the consoling power of sudden uncomplicated love.”

author: Ruth Prawer Jhabvala
title: “Aphrodisiac”
description: “Things began to change in the house. Actually, physically, they had begun to change soon after Naina’s arrival.”

author: George Saunders
title: Home
description: “Three cars for two grownups, I thought. What a country. What a couple of selfish dicks my wife and her new husband were.”

author: Tessa Hadley
title: Clever Girl
description: Fiction by Tessa Hadley: “When Madeleine and I went back to our different schools, the cult cooled down but didn’t die.”

author: David Foster Wallace
title: “Backbone”
description: Fiction: “Every whole person has ambitions, objectives, initiatives, goals. This one particular boy’s goal was to be able to press his lips to every square inch of his own body.”

author: Steven Millhauser
title: Getting Closer
description: “He knows exactly when it all begins: it begins when he enters the water. That’s the agreement he’s made with himself, summer after summer.”

author: David Means
title: The Tree Line, Kansas, 1934
description: Fiction by David Means: Carson’s men strode ahead, as if through the streets of Chicago, their black suit coats even blacker in the hazy light.

author: Nathan Englander
title: Nathan Englander: “Free Fruit for Young Widows”
description: “He was using the same word about the same people in the same desert that had been used thousands of years before.”

author: Jennifer Egan
title: “Ask Me If I Care”
description: Fiction: “One thing I’ve noticed: there are no real punk rockers with freckles. They don’t exist.”

author: Claire Keegan
title: Foster
description: A child, sent to stay with foster parents in rural Ireland while her mother gives birth, discovers a tragic secret.

author: David Foster Wallace
title: All That
description: “The toy cement mixer is the origin of the religious feeling that has informed most of my adult life.”

author: Javier Marías
title: While the Women Are Sleeping
description: “It isn’t the camera itself that interests me. ... It’s my girlfriend, whom you’ve seen, I’m sure. I film only her, nothing else.”

author: Lorrie Moore
title: Childcare
description: Fiction by Lorrie Moore: “In general, I thought of adoption much as I thought of most things in life: uneasily.”

author: Edna O'Brien
title: “Old Wounds”
description: Fiction: “Our families had a falling out. … Yet we were still intimately bound up with each other.”

author: Jonathan Lethem
title: Ava's Apartment
description: Fiction by Jonathan Lethem: “It turned out that it was possible to wish to become a dog only exactly up to that point where it became completely impossible.”

author: Salman Rushdie
title: “In the South”
description: Fiction: “To him the waves were Death itself and needed no other name.”

author: David Foster Wallace
title: “Wiggle Room”
description: Fiction: “The joke this week was: How was an I.R.S. rote examiner like a mushroom? Both kept in the dark and fed horseshit.”

author: Joyce Carol Oates
title: Pumpkin Head
description: “It did not seem to her a natural light, and in weak moments she thought, This is the crossing-over time.”

author: Colson Whitehead
title: “The Gangsters”
description: “According to the world, we were the definition of paradox: black boys with beach houses.”

author: Donald Antrim
title: Another Manhattan
description: “What kind of man courts a woman by letting her make an enormous bouquet for his wife, then asks her to pare back?”

author: J. M. G. Le Clézio
title: The Boy Who Had Never Seen the Sea

author: Sarah Shun-lien Bynum
title: Yurt
description: Fiction by Sarah Shun-lien Bynum: “A year ago, Ms. Duffy, the fifth-grade English and history teacher, had come very close to losing it.”

author: Annie Proulx
title: Annie Proulx: “Tits-Up in a Ditch”
description: “Way we see it,” Bonita said to Dakotah, “is you ought a join the Army yourself. They take women.”

author: Annie Proulx
title: Them Old Cowboy Songs
description: Travails of a homesteading couple

author: Ha Jin
title: The House Behind a Weeping Cherry
